summary:
I am a MEAL activist with over 8 years of pragmatic field and international experience in designing, coordinating, and implementing robust results-based M&E systems. 

I have worked in complex and small-scale programs and projects in Africa, Asia, and The Netherlands, guiding organizations and programs to define their results and anticipated change through methodologies such as the Theory of Change. Skilled in using efficient M&E techniques and frameworks to develop results-based plans for tracking project activities. I am also familiar with MEAL methodologies such as Outcome harvesting, outcome mapping (progress markers), Most Significant Change stories, and digital tools for measuring performance, and results. Knowledgeable in interpreting data from Monitoring and Evaluation activities into concrete learning and performance actions.
When I am not involved in MEAL activism and think tanks, I enjoy cooking, watching soccer, travelling, and catching up on a good laugh with friends.

projects.title: Vocational training for slum youth job creation and self-reliance
projects.description:
Support the establishment of a quality vocational and entrepreneurial skills training centre and educating youth will greatly help to reduce on the unemployment problem, provide and promote productive assets or opportunities that enable self-reliance among the disadvantaged communities of municipal Slums in Jinja municipality.  This opportunity also will help to curb down the vicious and intergenerational cycle of poverty among youth that tend flow from one generation to another.
 
The vocational skills will be imparted through direct provision of skills and apprenticeship. The organization plans to expand the existing training center to an annual capacity of 200 youth. Trainees will attend the morning and afternoon sessions. By the end of 24 months, 400 trainees will have graduated and then another intake will come. Training materials will be required for this project.

projects.title: COMPUTER LITERACY PROJECT IN RURAL COMMUNITIES
projects.description: To empower the youth and women in rural communities with computer education and this will include knowledge in computer programming and desktop publishing and technical skills in computer engineering – installation, assembly and repairs. Through providing education, job, technical, entrepreneurial and leadership skills to community members the project aims to reduce poverty, crime and illiteracy. In addition, we hope that IT skills will broaden the youths and women in rural communities’ career choices, integration into the urban/developed communities and enhance their communication skills and competitive advantage.

projects.title: Green Social Entreprenuer Youth Clubs
projects.description:
Green Youth Entrepreneurs at universities / Tertiary Institutions in Jinja is aimed at providing business skills and networks with local businesses to improve entrepreneurship and leadership skills and funds Green innovation initiatives. Youth will be empowered, creating sustainable and environmental initiatives partnering with community organisations.
2) How?
Clubs are given basic business training on developing entrepreneurial skills in finance, management,leadership, marketing, saving, resource mobilization, Communication, budgeting and Networking. Students will take lead in Green projects to reduce fuel consumption, waste, improve food production techniques and reduce carbon emissions from the school and community. Through a District-wide competition, the best ‘Green’ entrepreneur ideas will be given a platform, judged by community and enterprise leaders, with a grant given to support the best project. We will conduct a Training of Trainer(TOT) programme, and these will pass on the skills to new club members and each month clubs will hold a community workshop to demonstrate Green entrepreneurial skills (recycling, waste reduction,  to youths in their neighboring communities that are not in school and also provide mentor ship to these children.

projects.title: Young Adolescents Sexual and Reproductive Health Project
projects.description:
Girls and boys have a right to grow and develop in good health. For this to become a reality it is essential that sexual and reproductive health education that is accurate and appropriate to their stage of development is provided.  This is crucial for this type of education becomes the foundation for attitude formation and decision making.   Menstruation hygiene management (MHM) is a key topic in reproductive health education yet it is often overlooked in disadvantaged low socioeconomic status areas.
Good MHM is defined as the following:
1.	Providing access to necessary resources which include sanitary pads, materials needed to collect/absorb blood, soap and water. 
2.	Providing adequate private facilities where girls can change, wash themselves and their sanitary reusable pads. In addition facilities must include adequate disposal system.  
3.	Providing comprehensive health and sexual education related to MHM.  
An issue experienced in low SES areas of rural Uganda are the high dropout rates of girls due to poor MHM. This includes lack of washrooms at their schools, unavailability of sanitary pads, and bullying by peers. 
In addition the lack of proper health education leads to lack of prevention sexually transmitted infections. Other consequences of not addressing MHM properly include lack of sexually transmitted infections prevention education and lack of gender equality education and empowerment. 
•	Provide free reusable sanitary pads for 300 schoolgirls in remote districts of Jinja.
•	Write and disseminate culturally appropriate manual on menstrual hygiene practice targeting school teachers and girls in 150 schools in rural and peri-urban areas of Uganda.
•	Organize and train health clubs in schools in Jinja to teach and make reusable sanitary pads. Organize and mobilize such clubs and community organization to advocate for clean water, adequate private toilet facilities in schools and materials for girls.

projects.title: Clean Energy Saving Cook Stoves for Youths
projects.description:
‘’We Believe In Empowering youth to help themselves’’. Our strategy was aimed at building and strengthening capacities of local people through hands on skills and creating a favorable environment that enables vulnerable people to identify their strength, talents and potentials and turn them into business opportunities. We believed in transforming the informal education system in Uganda by providing skills for job creators but not job seekers. We offered skills that provided solution to un- employment and tackled poverty while utilising the environment sustainably.
 Project background	
We implemented an Improved Affordable Energy Saving Stoves for Youth Job Creation. This was a 1(one) year project that  begun in  January  2010 and  ended in December 2010.The project targeted  40 youths of age bracket 18-35 years in Kasubi parish from the four zones of  Kawaala I, Kawaala II, Kawaala central and Mugema zones in Rubaga Municipality.
The major project interventions included; mobilise and organise youth in business working groups, train them in group dynamics, entrepreneurship skills, making energy saving stoves, start your business package, link youth groups to government, NGOs and  private sector to access the existing funding opportunities for business start-up, train them in marketing and sales skills, monitoring and evaluation.

profile_positions.description:
Provide technical support and guidance to consultants and UNFPA country offices during the annual survey of monitoring and analysing financial expenditures for Family Planning and Reproductive Health activities in 34 countries in Asia and Africa.
•	Designed quantitative data monitoring and collection methods(survey) and tools(questionnaires).
•	Trained consultants on the use of the global database and guided them on data collection and entry.
•	Reviewed the data and provided timely feedback to consultants and the UNFPA country offices.
•	Round the clock technical support to consultants through routine phone calls and skype/zoom meetings 
•	Checked and analysed the data. Provided project management with timely progress reports.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate in the UNFPA-NIDI Resource Flows project on Family Planning.

profile_positions.description:
My Main responsibility
Design the M&E and data collection plan for two youths’ projects implemented in Uganda and Malawi.
•	Organized and facilitated conceptualization workshops (ToC) with over 25 key projects stakeholders.
•	Designed the results framework, including the results chain, indicators and tools for data-collection.
•	Trained 10 M&E field enumerators in collecting data for both M&E and learning purposes.
•	Provided the project team at the HQs with timely updates about the project progress and results.
•	Round the clock support to project teams through routine phone calls and skype calls.
profile_positions.title: International Monitoring, Evaluation and Research advisor

profile_positions.description:
My main responsibility included; 
Provide background literature and support the design of the Menstrual Health Management (MHM) program.
•	I conducted a stakeholder mapping of which I got about 30 key subject matter experts on MHM.
•	Conducted in-depths interviews with about 15 key international subject matter experts on MHM.
•	Drafted an evidence-based MHM program and training manual for MHM implementing partners.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant- Menstrual Health Management

profile_positions.description:
My main responsibility; 
Guide and build capacity in M&E of seven VSO partner organizations in Nigeria.
•	Conducted an M&E capacity assessment for 6 organizations to identify M&E capacity gaps.
•	Organized and facilitated workshops for 30 stakeholders in designing and developing MEAL systems.
•	Guided partners to design their own thematic and project-specific result chains including; log frames, indicators, data collection plans and tools.
•	Followed up all partner organizations to report their monitoring data through a centralised database
•	Ensured that the M&E programme specialist based at the HQs received round the clock updates on the M&E field activities
profile_positions.title: Monitoring And Evaluation Advisor

profile_positions.description:
My Main responsibilities; 
To create the M&E framework of a 10-year education project.
•	Developed a robust M&E system from scratch through several workshops with stakeholders.
•	Refined the results chain of the outcome, output and activities.
•	Developed verifiable indicators using the SMART approach
•	designed monitoring tools for tracking on enrolment, attendance and performance 
•	Targeted students achieved an 80% school completion rate in that project.
profile_positions.title: Monitoring and Evaluation Officer- Adolescents girls education project

volunteer_experiences.role: Project Coordinator- Emancipation of Men Project
volunteer_experiences.description:
•	As the coordinator. I was able to set up a project team of 3 technical persons and 10 volunteers to execute its mandate. 
•	I have also been able to identify and mobilize over 100 migrants and asylum seekers in the city of The Hague to participate in the project.
•	I have been at the forefront of designing a training module and also effected implementation and distribution of IEC materials for Men’s Emancipation
•	Facilitated training for 100 male immigrants. The focus of the training is on identity, outlook on life, education, empowerment of men, and the promotion of complementary relationships between men and women (couples).

Designed projects on Conflict, human rights and peace in Lebanon around a theme of Arts, culture, religion and Peace.
Designed a capacity building project for religious leaders and political leaders in Lebanon on economic and social empowerment

company.name: Department of CSOs-Office of The Governor Cross River State, Nigeria.

volunteer_experiences.description:
I conducted an enterprise capacity assessment for SME  in Cross River state, this was done through a baseline survey that involved mobilization, mentoring, grouping and assessment.
After the research i built a database of over 300 SMEs in different Local governments, these were categorized basing on their areas of specialization and operation.
Facilitated the capacity building exercise that involved training, mentoring and coaching of selected members from these SMEs

Design of income generating projects for underprivileged women in Cameroon.Through these projects we were able to build capacity for groups of women through skills acquisition for income generation and business enterprise management.
